resource.name: Connecticut Nurses Census 1917
resource.description: Connecticut Nurses Census 1917 The Connecticut Nurses Census is a part of State Archives Record Group 029: Records of the Military Census Department. The census forms may give basic details such as birthplace, age, marital status, maiden name, and current residence, as well as more specific information such as the name of the nursing school attended, medical specialty, and year of licensure. This census included the registration of both female and male nurses. This index includes the name, birthplace, age, current residence, form number and box number. If a field is left blank, it is because the person who submitted the form did not answer that question (e.g. age, anybody!) People may request a copy of a census form by contacting us by telephone (860) 757-6580 or email. Please include the name of the individual and form number.

resource.name: Connecticut Vital Records — Index of Marriages, 1897-2001
resource.description: Connecticut Vital Records — Index of Marriages, 1897-2001 This index allows researchers to find the name, place and date of marriage for couples who were married in Connecticut between 1897 through 2001. The information from this index can be used to request a copy of a marriage certificate from the Town/City Clerk of the municipality listed in the search results. Order forms for vital records requests can be found at this link. There is no guarantee that the information contained in the index is accurate and the State of Connecticut has no legal liability for any claims resulting from reliance on this information.
resource.attribution: State Vital Records Office / Connecticut State Library

resource.name: Connecticut Paupers 1844 – 1907
resource.description: Index to Town Claims to the Connecticut State Comptroller for payment for care of State Paupers, 1844-1907 In February of 1846, the Connecticut State Comptroller, Abijah Carrington received an urgent letter from the selectmen of the Town of Newtown. They were seeking to inform the Comptroller that a transient individual by the name of Ephriam Rixon had appeared in that community seven weeks earlier and had applied for town assistance. As a result, the town had supported Mr. Rixon since that time. The Selectmen of Newtown were putting Mr. Carrington on notice as State Comptroller that they would be requesting that the State of Connecticut be held liable financially for the care and support for Mr. Rixon as provided by Connecticut state law. This simple document not only served a necessary bureaucratic function but highlighted the life of an individual in need. From this single, short, primary source document we learn that Ephriam Rixon was from Sweden and about seventy years of age in 1846. Further, it indicates that he came to this country some forty years earlier (circa 1806) and had never established himself as a resident of a single community. Such information holds great value to local historians and family genealogists researching people from all social and economic backgrounds. This document also provides important information on the migration patterns of people in Connecticut and beyond during the 19th century. This item is one of thousands of such documents found in the Connecticut State Archives as part of archival record group (RG) # 008, Records of the Connecticut State Comptroller, Town Claims for State Paupers, 1844-1920. These documents detail the lives of individuals, or whole families, facing an uncertain future in Connecticut during a time of great economic and social upheaval. Personal information such as individual names, ages, place of prior origin (whether another Connecticut municipality, state or foreign country), time spent in Connecticut along with other migration patterns such as entry into the United States and movement in the country as well as the specific cause or need for support may be included. Destitution, illness, accidents, childbirth or burial fees, and costs for passage home are just a few of the possible support details listed on these documents which may shed light on the plight of individuals and families during that time. To bring to light these individual’s stories and provide better access to these underutilized records, the staff of the Connecticut State Library has created an index to much of these records covering the 1844 to June of 1907 time-period and encompassing thousands of documents and over 11,500 database entries. This index includes the individual’s surname and given name, Connecticut city or town submitting the letter to the State Comptroller, date of letter, remarks of note document, as well as the citation of where the original item was found in the State Comptroller records in the Connecticut State Archives. People may request a copy of the letter by contacting the History & Genealogy Unit staff by telephone (860) 757-6580 or by email. The request should include the name of the individual, Connecticut location, date of original letter, and the specific archival box and folder citation as provided in the database. Please understand that some records may be extremely fragile and may not be able to be reproduced or read with ease. For more information about records of the Connecticut State Comptroller stored at the Connecticut State Library, please see a scanned copy of the old finding aid to this collection at: Records of the Connecticut State Comptroller, 1758-1954. Terminology Disclaimer Please be advised that some of the terminology used in the original resource documents–particularly those created in previous eras–contain descriptions for ancestral, racial, ethn

resource.name: HVAC Indoor Air Quality Grant Program for Public Schools Awards
resource.description:
This dataset includes award data for the HVAC Indoor Air Quality Grant Program for Public Schools for Round 1 (FY23) and Round 2 (FY24). 

Information about the reimbursement rates used in this program can be found on the DAS website here: https://portal.ct.gov/das/office-of-grants-administration/school-construction-state-reimbursement-percentages?language=en_US
columns_description: Total project amount that the reimbursement rate is applied to
Award amount that is reimbursed by the state based off reimbursement rate defined in CGS 102-85a
Fiscal year in which the district applied and the grant was awarded

resource.name: Wethersfield Prison Records 1800-1903
resource.description:
The Wethersfield State Prison opened in September 1827 with the transfer of eighty-one prisoners from Newgate Prison. Modeled after the state-of-the-art Auburn State Prison in New York, Wethersfield provided solitary confinement for the prisoners and facilities for various workshops. In 1963, all prisoners from Wethersfield were transferred to a new State Prison at Somers and two years later Wethersfield State Prison was demolished.

The Warrants of Commitment, 1800-1903, contain the name of the prisoner, any known aliases, the crime, sentence, court, and date of incarceration. This information can be used to determine the probable location of court records relating to the individual prisoners.

People may request a copy of a file by contacting the staff of the History & Genealogy Unit by telephone (860) 757-6580 or email. When requesting a copy of a record, please include at least the name of the individual and date.

resource.name: Connecticut Vital Records — Index of Deaths, 1897-2001
resource.description: Connecticut Vital Records — Index of Deaths, 1897-2001 This index allows researchers to find the name, place and date of death for individuals who died in Connecticut between 1897 through 2001. The information from this index can be used to request a copy of a death certificate from the Town/City Clerk of the municipality listed in the search results. Order forms for vital records requests can be found at this link. There is no guarantee that the information contained in the index is accurate and the State of Connecticut has no legal liability for any claims resulting from reliance on this information. Use the search box to find names. Click the "filter" button in the column menus to do a more precise search. You can use full or partial spelling of names (partial spellings may yield more results —as many first name entries use only the first four or five letters of the name).
resource.attribution: State Vital Records Office / Connecticut State Library

resource.name: Noble Pension Database
resource.description:
Connecticut State Archives Archival Record Group (RG) #069:050, Noble (William H. and Henrietta) Pension Applications

General William H. Noble and his daughter Henrietta M. Noble, Pension Agents in Bridgeport, assisted veterans and their descendants to secure pensions from the United States Government. The collection includes correspondence and official papers that document their work with veterans of the Civil War and Spanish American War. The files are arranged alphabetically by veteran’s name.

The database contains the following information: veteran’s name, rank, pension file application number, date enlisted, date discharged, and military unit.

People may request a copy of a file by contacting the staff of the History & Genealogy Unit by telephone (860) 757-6580 or email. When requesting a copy of a record, please include at least the name of the individual, date, and residence.

Abbreviations of Connecticut Military Branch of Service:

· CLB – Connecticut Light Battery
· CVA – Connecticut Volunteer Artillery
· CVC – Connecticut Volunteer Cavalry
· CVHA – Connecticut Volunteer Heavy Artillery
· CVI – Connecticut Volunteer Infantry
· CVLB – Connecticut Volunteer Light Battery
